narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: I think this class had the potential to be great, but honestly I was a bit disappointed. The lectures were interesting, but the problem sets and exams were particularly tedious and I don't feel like they really tested our knowledge of the class material. Instead, the problem sets turned out to be a game of how well you can search the Internet for information to find certain data sets and the exam was how fast you could look through your notes to find very specific details, instead of holistic/systematic questions for what we learned in class. I just really felt like there was a huge disparity between what we learned in class and what we were tested/graded on.
This course has a lot of potential and the instructor is clearly very knowledgeable, but I do not think the material is presented in an organized way that facilitates learning.
The problem sets are little bit overloaded to me.The course content is very impressive.
The instructor seemed to dislike students' questions.

Grubler is really one of a kind. Just an amazing lecturer + brilliant guy. He really approaches energy from such a unique/interesting perspective. Really feel privileged to take his course. The guy has a big ego and can be condescending but that actually makes me like him more. Fits the Austrian "tough love" mentality. Such a nice/helpful guy if you talk to him after class.

The content of the course is exactly what I am interested in, but, the lecture style and format made it very difficult to really get a lot from them. Bowers is not a good room for a 3 hour lecture, especially when the professor refuses to wear a microphone. It was often very dark in the room and hard to hear him if you were not sitting in the front couple of rows (which filled up very quickly). It would have been much easier to learn if this was a 2 day per week class, rather than 1 time 3 hour class. The style of the lectures also made it hard to really learn because it was not structured in an easy to follow manner. The timing of when and how things were presented in lecture, did not follow with when and how they were asked on the homework. It was also often very hard to discern which pieces of information were the professor's opinion and which were facts.

For question 1, the Energy Primer was extremely useful. The others were not.Question 12 - Arnulf has a wealth of knowledge related to the energy sector that is likely unrivaled pretty much anywhere. That said, I found that sometimes the tangents he would go on were a bit disengaging, and I found the problem sets to be quite disorganized at times. More on that below. I did appreciate his honesty and the strength of the perspective he brought to the class. That said, I wish he had had a little more objectivity in some of the comments he made, recognizing a bit more that there are multiple sides to certain topics.
no comment
N/A
The professor was neither encouraging or helpful to a majority of the students and was difficult to approach.

Arnulf is awesome. He provided a framework for the world's energy systems, including a sense of magnitude. I'd been trying to learn this for years, but gotten nowhere as the information was difficult for me to assimilate from the wide array of sources that exist. He's also pretty damn funny when he wants to be. He's not for the faint of heart though. I'm confident that some people took his teaching style the wrong way, but that wasn't me. I loved his class and think he's a great teacher.
After covering determinants of energy systems, the section on climate change felt disorganized and unfocused.
This is the kind of stuff I came to Yale for. I'll be taking this course with me far out into my career.
This course was excellent. I am just getting started in the field of energy studies, and this course provided the knowledge foundation I needed to progress to more advanced courses in the field.

I think that more guidance from the TAs would have helped a lot on our assignments. I also felt like I spent a lot of time not learning or working on my homework, just data mining on the Internet which took up too much unnecessary time.

Lectures and guest lectures

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: Meet more often, please!
The problem sets and exams definitely need improvement. They do not seem to correlate well with the class material at the moment.
Delivery of information and the problem sets

Hard to determine which points were most important during lectures. Also, majority of work was very detailed, specific problem sets that didn't reinforce concepts tested on the midterm and final, which made up 50% of the grade.
More clarification on the expectations for the exam
too much work load
too focused on problem sets.

Grubler's lecture slides are not as helpful as they could be. They sort of follow the minimalist/engineering format. The problem sets should be a little easier + not rely so much on data mining. I loved this course but it did take up too much of my time this semester.

Room change/class size. Splitting the class into 2 sessions per week. The TAs should have office hours to assist with questions - they were only available via email, and it was often hard to communicate questions this way.

The problem sets and the time commitment. I thought that the modules were a bit overkill, especially for someone who is often committed during the evenings, and I didn't feel like I missed out on a lot when I wasn't able to attend all of certain modules. In terms of the problem sets, I found them to be TOO overwhelming and unnecessarily vague and disorganized. There were frequently errors in the spreadsheets, and many of the questions were worded in ways that i simply couldn't understand.It shouldn't require asking the TA for an explanation of what the question is asking as frequently as I had to. I think the problem sets could have been shortened by a question or two and still had a significant impact on our learning.I also felt that the final exam wasn't an accurate representation of what I learned in the course. Unlike the midterm, it was TOO challenging for the limited time we had in which to complete it, and it left me asking myself how much I really did learn in the course. I'm not asking for a piece of cake test, but one in which I can at least feel somewhat proud of how i did, which I found not to be the case at all from the many people I talked to afterwards.Finally, I do feel that while there is something to be said for decoupling the assignments from the lectures in terms of allowing more time to cover more ground, i thought that spending at least SOME time during the lecture portion discussing conversions and other key concepts that relate to the problem sets would be helpful and would solidify our understanding that much more.

The one-long-lecture-per-week format is too much information to learn effectively. Also I understand the point of the problem sets is to practice skills but some of the data research is unnecessary to teach the equations.

The three hour lecture format is not conducive to learning. Nobody can pay attention the whole time! Grubler's condescending way of addressing students is also detrimental to our learning. He literally would have slides up about important concepts (e.g. modeling) and tell us we weren't smart enough to understand them, so he wouldn't explain. Additionally, the problem set instructions were often very unclear and on material that we hadn't always seen before. It's ok to add material to the course by first introducing things in a problem set, but if that's what you're doing, more clear instructions would help!

My only critique is that Climate Change got wrapped into both the environment section and two lectures of its own, making it taught a little haphazardly while discussing transitions may have been more interesting and novel.

The third Professional Module was not very helpful. Peter's and Arnulf's sections were good. The other two not so much.Professor Grubler can occasionally be a little bit mean. I know that's just his style, but I think it rubs some students the wrong way.The final exam is so difficult that it makes you feel as if you didn't learn anything. Having us all get 30%s doesn't prove anything other than that Professor Grubler can put together a nasty test. It would benefit the students' learning more to have a (slightly) easier test.
would be nice to have clearer instructions for the homework
Lectures too long and sometimes too complicated. Assignement difficult, time-consuming and not oftentimes clearly explained (point was missing).
The class size was too big and sometimes questions from students went far off topic.
The material needs to be more organized, the problem sets should focus more on critical thinking rather than just searching for data.

I found the problem sets to be helpful in understanding the material to a point, though most of my time spent on the problem sets was spent deciphering the vague wording and mining documents and sources for just the right number/ piece of information.I also didn't appreciate the poor and inconsistent communication about changes in the midterm schedule (I bought a plane ticket after the syllabus was handed out that I ended up having to lose because the midterm's date was changed) and a lack of description about what was allowed in the midterm. Sometimes all class materials were allowed, other times only notes--no lectures. I spent a lot of time summarizing graphs from the lectures to my notes that other people interpreted as allowed. Clearer communication would have helped with this.These problems were remedied during the final.
Sometimes it was difficult to read a question in a problem set and be able to get started on identifying the proper data source. But I think that was part of the goal... locating information.
the clarity of the questions on the problem sets and tests (it was often unclear) and the lectures on modeling (they were over the heads of most students, very technical).
Consider going into more depth on models.
i was hoping for more in the modeling section. i would have loved to do some kind of hands-on project with that material (to the extent possible given my background).
class scheduling

The course should not be held in Bowers auditorium if possible. The dim lighting makes it difficult to focus on Dr. Grubler, especially from the back half of the room. It's also very drafty and uncomfortably cold. These two together can make it difficult to concentrate on the lecture.Also, though the problem sets were useful they did not directly reinforce the concepts taught in lecture. Working an explicit review of the broader concepts (as opposed to the status quo of all application) into the assignments for the course would be helpful.
The integration of lectures with all other aspects of the course.
The different modeling tools presented I think were a bit to abstract for most of us. They should be presented as an optional module for people truly interested in using them for future work.
Classes should not be 3 hours long. Class should be twice a week for 1.5 hours each. Slides should be better organized and better explain material. Professional modules should be better managed/run.
The problem sets could focus more on analyzing results than on finding data.

Quality of guest lectures is somewhat variable.Later problem sets could have slightly reduced emphasis on finding data, conversion factors, etc., which while instructive for the earlier problem sets, becomes merely time-consuming in the later ones with relatively little pedagogical value gained.

The tests were terrible. The midterm especially was disappointing because we were tested on statistics rather then concepts or mathematical analysis. I think being tested on statistical facts was uncalled for when there were more important things to learn in the class. Further, the wording on the problem sets are very confusing and difficult to understand. This really needs to improve.
Some of the problem set questions were unclear and too open to multiple interpretations.

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Get started on the PS early
I think Arnulf really needs to reconsider the problem sets and exams for the course.
Although the problem sets are tough, the course is worth taking.
If you are really into Energy, this course is for you.But you need to deal with tons of raw data and data mining which will eventually and ironically get rid of all your excitement for this course.
It's a hard course. The problem sets are daunting. You will hate Grubler a few times over the course of the year. You will love him at other times. Enjoy the ride. Take it.
I would recommend this course.

Not an easy class, but definitely a must if you have any interest in working in the energy sector. Yes, you can learn some of the conversions on your own, but unless you force yourself to practice them it ain't gonna happen! Arnulf's perspective is also quite entertaining and worth being exposed to, as he is legendary here at Yale!
Be prepared to devote a lot of time, but you will learn more about a subject that you need to know about and probably don't than any other FES class.

Work with your peers on problem sets and in preparing exam study materials, such as a summary of the Primer. Memorize the important numbers. Read the primer many times. Go to Grubler's office hours, as he's actually quite helpful and nice when he's one-on-one with a student. Apparently you're supposed to put formulas in the cells on the answer tab of problem sets (they don't tell you this...). Get super detailed in the "assumptions" boxes on problem sets.

I think this class is excellent. It's a survey of energy, covering far more than you new existed, while also going into detail and really just giving you exposure to different ways of thinking. Whether it is modeling, examining why and how we use energy and how that may change, or just hearing excellent analogies, this class is great.

If you care at all about energy or climate, you need to take ESA. It is fantastic. Grubler is an evil genius. The problem sets are horrific. The final exam is impossible. The moonshine hit the spot. I learned a ton.
be prepared for all the work
Take it. A lot of work but worth it. Learn to ignore Grubler and his attitude.
Make sure you have the time and energy for the course, otherwise it will take away from your schedule elsewhere.

Take it. Especially if you're looking for a broad survey of energy topics as opposed to skills development or basic principles.While I learned a lot in this class, if you are not planning on doing your own research, it would really help to have other classes in Energy offered so that Arnulf's perspective is not the only perspective you get. He can't possibly cover everything needed in the depth it is needed in order to knowledgeably work in the energy field.

It depends somewhat on your personality (Arnulf jokes a lot). If you're too serious and sensitive, the class may not work for you. But if you want to get a solid understanding of the world's energy systems, this class is for you!

Be prepared for a lot or work. Much of the work on the problem sets is simply finding the data you need to complete the mathematical problems. also the tests in this class are unconventional--they are very difficult (especially the final) and you will not finish the problems and you will be graded on a curve.

Not worth it, don't take this class. Just read the energy primer. Energy systems analysis was a poorly organized class and the professor did not do a good job of teaching his students anything beyond a regurgitation of the reading material. I learned more from reading the assigned readings.
Budget enough time for problem sets.
take it! it's worth the effort!
start the problem sets right after class. material is fresh and you will mae substantial gains right away. stay to talk to the class speakers as much as you can

Start the problem sets early and work with other students! Don't underestimate the exams, because they are extremely difficult. And go to Dr. Grubler's office hours, becausehe's very willing to talk further about anything related (or not so related) to energy. Great course! Hard but totally worth it.
This course gives you a great foundation for energy. So if you don't have it, take it!

Overall an excellent course.Do be prepared for the heavy workload.
